author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: Fossil Holds Clues to How Some Owls Evolved Into Daytime Hunters
description: The bird, which sought prey in a part of China 6 million years ago, had eyes shaped in a way that suggest it was not nocturnal like most owls living today.
content: In the silty red soil of Gansu Province in China, a small owl has lain nestled for about 6 million years, since an era known as the Late Miocene. The fossilized bird’s talons are outstretched, one of its wings is spread wide and its sharp beak is turned back over its shoulder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Why Putin name-checked J.K. Rowling
description: Putin has used scaremongering about gender and sexual orientation to support his authoritarian agenda. Right-wing politicians around the world are following the same playbook.
content: It would be easy to start this newsletter by commenting on how odd it was that Putin took time out of a televised address, in the midst of a war, to complain that the West was being too mean to J.K. Rowling. During a speech on Friday, he claimed that Western elites had “canceled” the Harry Potter author because she “did not please fans of so-called gender freedoms.” (In fact, though Rowling’s views have led many to accuse her of transphobia, her career is just fine.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: A Childhood Home of Gloria Vanderbilt Finally Finds a Buyer
description: The Upper East Side mansion, which has been divided into three luxury units, narrowly avoided foreclosure and sold for $32.2 million, the top sale in March.
content: The Upper East Side mansion where the socialite Gloria Vanderbilt spent part of her early childhood has been sold for $32.2 million, topping the list of March closings in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Covid, Russia and Economy Put the ‘China Model’ to the Test
description: With China’s prosperity and global standing seemingly at risk, some are wondering — aloud — whether the country is on the wrong track.
content: A year ago, while many countries were still reeling from Covid-19, China seemed to be one of few places prospering through the pandemic. It was also the only major economy that reported growth in 2020. Global investors were bullish on Chinese stocks even as Beijing’s regulatory crackdown on its private sector became more like a political campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Richard Howard, Acclaimed Poet and Translator, Is Dead at 92
description: His poetry won him a Pulitzer Prize, and his translations introduced numerous French writers to English-speaking audiences.
content: Richard Howard, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet who made the venerable genre of the dramatic monologue speak in a modern voice, and whose translations brought the work of Roland Barthes, Alain Robbe-Grillet and dozens of other French writers to an Anglophone audience, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Levin and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Instructions for Stopping
description: This poem gives us hope to imagine and construct a nonviolent future.
content: I first read this poem in the anthology “Bullets Into Bells: Poets & Citizens Respond to Gun Violence.” This poem sat alongside Kate Ranta’s description of being shot by her ex-husband in front of her 4-year-old son. Dana Levin is the modern-day master of the em dash (Dickinson is the other). In the first section, the em dash mimics breathing out. In the second section, breathing in. And in the final section, “Who offers love,/who terror — ” it acts more like a question mark. I also love how this poem gives us instructions through the imperative — meaning, the poem is giving us hope to imagine and construct a nonviolent future. Selected by Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Apuzzo and Benjamin Novak
title: In Hungary, Viktor Orban Remakes an Election to His Liking
description: The populist prime minister, a hero to many American conservatives, has changed voting rules and legalized ‘voter tourism’ as he stands for re-election
content: BUDAPEST — During the dark winter of the 2020 coronavirus wave, the Hungarian government set up a website so anxious residents could sign up for the news on the pandemic. For months, the system sent out updates about the virus, testing and where to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia, Anton Troianovski and Steven Erlanger
title: More Mixed Signals From Russia as Ukraine War Enters Sixth Week
description: Moscow appeared to adjust its position on humanitarian access to Mariupol, but there was little evidence to support Russian claims of a military pullback near Kyiv.
content: KRAKOW, Poland — Facing deeper isolation by the day over the Ukraine war, Russia seemed to slightly recalibrate its stance Thursday, allowing greater humanitarian access to the devastated port city of Mariupol and apparently retreating from a payment confrontation with European gas customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: Bolsonaro Said His ‘Specialty Is Killing.’ He’s Been True to His Word.
description: Brazil’s president has the planet in his cross hairs.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — “I’m an army captain,” Jair Bolsonaro said in 2017. “My specialty is killing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Recap: Neither Seen Nor Heard
description: This week, “Picard” increases the stakes with unpredictable villains and ancestors with a lot to lose.
content: OK, kids: The word of the day in this week’s “Picard” is Ancestor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Wall Street rebounded in March even as worries grew over Ukraine and inflation.
description: Stocks rose 3.6 percent in March, after the S&P 500 rebounded sharply from its lowest point of the year.
content: Inflation accelerated, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine grew more intense, the Federal Reserve started to cool down the economy and some investors began to wonder if a recession is looming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: A Whitney Biennial of Shadow and Light
description: After three years of soul-rattling history, this year’s survey at the Whitney Museum of American Art is reflective and adult-thinking. It opens to the public April 6.
content: After a year’s Covid delay, the latest Whitney Biennial has pulled into town, and it’s a welcome sight. Other recent editions — this is the 80th such roundup — have tended to be buzzy, jumpy, youthquake affairs. This one, even with many young artists among its 60-plus participants, most represented by brand-new, lockdown-made work, doesn’t read that way. It’s a notably somber, adult-thinking show, one freighted with three years of soul-rattling history marked by social divisiveness, racist violence and relentless mortality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: A Filmmaker’s Journey to the Center of Celine Dion
description: In her kooky, rambunctious biopic “Aline,” the French comedian Valérie Lemercier drew from her own life to play the Quebecois pop star at every stage of hers.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Avoid tax and charity scams this spring.
description: Along with the annual wave of tax-related phishing attempts, fake Ukrainian war-relief charities are flooding the internet.
content: Fraud is a year-round activity, but tax season brings an uptick in calculated schemes to steal money and personal information through spoofed messages and other means. Cybersecurity firms have also reported an increase in fraud attempts that exploit the conflict in Ukraine — a situation that has increased fears of potential cyberattacks on American companies. Our Tech Tip columnist, J.D. Biersdorfer, reports that you can better protect yourself if you know what’s out there. Here’s a guide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: A Farmer’s Dozen From Bordeaux
description: These 12 wines, made by vignerons and not grand estates, are classically refreshing and altogether inviting.
content: Sales of Bordeaux in the United States took off last year, rising by 24 percent in volume, according to the Bordeaux Wine Council, a trade group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: ‘Turning Red’ Is Not a Credit to the Asian Race. That’s Why It’s Good.
description: The perils of caring too much about the politics of racial representation.
content: Last week, I watched “Turning Red,” the new Pixar movie by Domee Shi, with my 5-year-old daughter. It is about a 13-year-old Chinese-Canadian girl named Mei who is trying to navigate adolescence, friendship and the demands of her overbearing mother. There’s not much to spoil about the film, but I’ll just leave it at this: After a moment of extreme humiliation at the hands of her mother, Mei turns into a giant red panda who can perform great acts of athletic prowess. She soon realizes that she can control when she becomes a panda and when she turns back into studious, anxious Mei. Also, there is a boy band that Mei and her friends are obsessed with. The question at the center of the story is one of authenticity and knowing one’s true self: Is Mei the red panda or is she her mother’s cowering daughter?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Barbarians’ Review: Unexpected Visitors
description: In this new thriller set in the countryside, tension mounts between two men until a home invasion takes it to homicidal heights.
content: The new thriller “Barbarians” might look familiar to those acquainted with the director Lars von Trier’s 2009 film, “Antichrist.” Both movies center on a wealthy couple in the countryside destined for violent encounters, as portended by a dying fox. But where “Antichrist” depicts a crisis of femininity, as a wife is overtaken by madness, “Barbarians,” in the directorial debut by Charles Dorfman, is all about masculinity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘I Agree to the Terms,’ It’s Raining Pennies From Amazon
description: The Builders Association explores the world of turkers, workers performing thousands of weird, low-paying tasks for an online giant.
content: A place where “information is free” and “money isn’t everything”: That’s how Stewart Brand, the longtime editor of the Whole Earth Catalog, foresaw the future of the internet in 1985.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: The Grammys, Always Unpredictable, Face New Surprises
description: The lead-up to the awards has involved controversy over a last-minute ballot change, Covid-19 cases, a nominee’s death and, of course, The Slap. But producers say the show will be ready.
content: This was supposed to be the year the Grammy Awards got back to normal. In 2021, the pandemic delayed the ceremony by six weeks and led organizers to put on a stripped-down outdoor show with no audience, which charmed critics with its intimate look yet had anemic ratings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Pump Your Own Gas? No Thanks, Say New Jerseyans
description: A brief but intense push to change a law that forbids self-service gas stations stalled before it even revved up.
content: Sabrina Banks, an 18-year-old college freshman, has never pumped her own gasoline. Growing up in New Jersey, she never had to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: A Director Returns (Uncomfortably) to His Working-Class Roots
description: Christophe Honoré’s latest work, for the Paris stage, is part of a recent wave of stories in France about the complex aftereffects of social mobility.
content: PARIS — The French director Christophe Honoré, best known for films including “Love Songs” and “Sorry Angel,” has been making exceptional work in recent years — and international audiences have been missing out on it. The reason? It’s happening on theater stages in his home country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: What is the Wagner Group?
description: The private Russian military force, which has close ties to President Vladimir Putin and has been used in war zones across the world, is expanding its presence in Ukraine.
content: Unless you have been on the battlefield in Syria, Libya or the Central African Republic, you most likely have never heard of the Wagner Group, a private military force with close links to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The U.S. imposes sanctions on Russian technology companies and evasion networks.
description: Some of the new sanctions focus on organizations that supply or support Russia’s defense sector.
content: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department on Thursday leveled new sanctions on Russian technology companies and illicit procurement networks that the country is using to evade existing sanctions, expanding the Biden administration’s effort to punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine by crippling its economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Where Are People Less Lonely?
description: Not all U.S. states are equal when it comes to the struggles of living single.
content: Being single can come with logistical, economic and emotional challenges. Whether or not one is solo by choice, loneliness can set in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Union Trails in Amazon Vote in Alabama, With Challenges Pending
description: The count was much closer than another unionization vote taken at the facility last year.
content: Union supporters are narrowly trailing opponents in a union election at an Amazon warehouse in Alabama, the National Labor Relations Board said on Thursday. But the count was far closer than a vote at the same warehouse last year, when workers rejected the union by a more than 2-to-1 ratio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Prize Money and Sponsorships Are Growing in Women’s Golf, but Is It Enough?
description: Golfers will compete for a $5 million purse when the L.P.G.A.’s first major of the season begins on Thursday. But women continue to lag far behind men.
content: Brittany Lincicome started playing on the L.P.G.A. Tour in 2005, when it was a struggling endeavor with few events. Now, in her 18th season, the tour is thriving and she has no plans to retire any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Bradley
title: Melvin Edwards, Sam Gilliam and William T. Williams: Abstract Artists and Old Friends
description: The trio first had their work exhibited together at the Studio Museum in Harlem in 1969. Now, Pace Gallery is showing some of the pieces they’ve made since.
content: “Do one thing for me,” the sculptor Melvin Edwards says, “don’t use a musical metaphor.” A chastened journalist revokes his offending word, “riff,” used to describe Edwards’s back and forth with the painters Sam Gilliam and William T. Williams, friends for more than fifty years, during an interview done in anticipation of “Epistrophy,” the trio’s joint exhibition of recent and historic works opening this week at Pace Gallery in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘The Devil You Know’ Review: A Thriller Thinner Than Blood
description: This misbegotten family drama, starring a squandered all-Black ensemble, begins with stolen baseball cards.
content: Recently released from prison, Marcus Cowans (Omar Epps), a recovering alcoholic, searches for a fresh start. He comes from a steadfast family, of four flatly sketched siblings, who worry about his well-being. But it’s his brother Drew (William Catlett), unemployed, alone, and hanging around a bad crowd, who’s concerning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Smiling
description: What do you know or think you know about this image and where it is from?
content: What do you know or think you know about this image and where it is from? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mercedes Lilienthal
title: A Rugged Newcomer Looks to Fill a Void Left by Land Rover
description: The Grenadier from INEOS Automotive, brought to life by the billionaire Jim Ratcliffe, is poised to arrive this year.
content: HAMBACH, France — After a 33-year production run, the last original Land Rover Defender was built in 2016, ending a rugged-yet-refined era for off-road pursuits. Jaguar Land Rover, owned by Tata Motors, part of an Indian conglomerate, shifted its focus to luxury and technology with plans for a new 4x4, also named Defender but disconnected from its predecessors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Ukraine has asked for ‘security guarantees’ to make peace with Russia. What does that mean?
description: Ukraine’s request for other countries to guarantee its future security as a condition for making concessions to Moscow is circulating among European diplomats. But analysts say such a demand faces huge obstacles.
content: With peace talks between Russia and Ukraine sporadic and inconclusive, a seemingly arcane but potentially significant diplomatic fix has been circulating in Europe’s corridors of power: Giving Ukraine security guarantees to enable an agreement with Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: A new U.S. government website aims to help Americans find Covid antiviral pills.
description: As the coronavirus pandemic moves into what the White House hopes is a “new normal,” the Biden administration has introduced covid.gov, a federal website meant to help Americans who are infected with the virus find the treatment they need quickly and at no cost.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic moves into what the White House hopes is a “new normal,” the Biden administration has introduced covid.gov, a federal website meant to help Americans who are infected with the virus find the treatment they need quickly and at no cost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘You Won’t Be Alone’ Review: Season of the Witch
description: A supernaturally altered young woman learns how to be human in this mesmerizing folk-horror tale.
content: “You Won’t Be Alone,” the ravishing, wildly original first feature from Goran Stolevski, moves so hypnotically between dream and nightmare, horror and fairy tale that, once bound by its spell, you won’t want to be freed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About How Social Media Affects Their Body Image
description: A recent article put a spotlight on how social media can fuel body dysmorphia in boys. We asked teenagers how these apps make them feel about the way they look.
content: Please note: This post is part of The Learning Network’s ongoing Current Events Conversation feature in which we invite students to react to the news via our daily writing prompts and publish a selection of their comments each week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Arizona Passes Proof-of-Citizenship Law for Voting in Presidential Elections
description: Voting rights groups said the legislation signed into law by Gov. Doug Ducey, a Republican, could prevent tens of thousands of people from voting for president.
content: Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona has signed legislation requiring voters to prove their citizenship in order to vote in a presidential election, swiftly drawing a legal challenge from voting rights activists who argued that it could keep tens of thousands of voters from casting a ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: Tiptoeing at a ‘Toad Ceremony’
description: For a recent article on the Sonoran desert toad and its psychedelic secretions, a photographer attended a spiritual ceremony to witness the drug’s effect.
content: The participants smoked, one at a time. When the drug kicked in, all but one moaned and screamed. Go Nakamura, a photographer for The Times, crept softly with his shutter off to avoid casting a shadow in the frame or making a sound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Dimwitted Mammals Needed Muscle More Than Brains After Dinosaurs Died
description: It may have been the smart evolutionary strategy during a chaotic chapter of Earth’s history, but it didn’t last.
content: Mammals are the brainiacs of the animal world. The brain of the sperm whale is the largest on Earth, at a hefty 20 pounds, while your three-pound brain is seven times as large as expected for the average human body. Collectively, mammals have the largest ratio of brain to body size among vertebrates, a fact that helps to explain their cognitive ability. Bigger brains are often better at coordinating complex behavior, solving puzzles and responding to environmental change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Countertop Privilege
description: One man has enough space to put out appliances just as a joke.
content: Jeff writes: Our coffee maker is dying. I’d like to replace it with two Bunn coffee makers. Then I could point them out to guests and say, “Nice Bunns!” — an exquisite dad joke that would never get old. My partner disagrees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
title: Rising Wages Could Complicate America’s Inflation Cool-Down
description: Economists hoped that as households shifted spending back to services, price gains would cool. That effect might be less pronounced now.
content: Economists have been waiting for Americans to shift from buying goods, like furniture and appliances, and toward spending on vacations, restaurant meals and other services as the pandemic fades, betting the transition would take pressure off supply chains and help inflation to moderate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Ginni Thomas’s Texts, and the Limits of Chief Justice Roberts’s Power
description: His title notwithstanding, the chief justice cannot force a colleague’s recusal. If Justice Clarence Thomas is to disqualify himself, it will be his decision.
content: WASHINGTON — In the wake of revelations about incendiary text messages from Virginia Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, to the Trump White House, mostly in the weeks leading up to the Jan. 6 attack, Democrats in Congress urged Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. to take action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: 12 New Books Coming in April
description: Novels from Jennifer Egan and Emily St. John Mandel, poetry by Ocean Vuong and nonfiction from Elizabeth Alexander. Plus: Did jealousy conceal the true inventor of the motion picture?
content: Drawing on the lives and struggles of many pioneering artists — Alice Neel, Jenny Offill, Audre Lorde, Doris Lessing and others — Phillips offers a rich inquiry into the space where inspiration, creative work and motherhood converge. “What does it mean to create, not alone in ‘a room of one’s own,’ but in a shared space?,” she asks. “What is the shape of a creative mother’s life?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Testify or Pay Up, Judge Tells Alex Jones in Sandy Hook Suit
description: A Connecticut judge rejected the Infowars conspiracy theorist’s claim that he was too ill to sit for a deposition, and set a schedule of hefty fines.
content: A Connecticut judge, exasperated by the Infowars broadcaster Alex Jones’s “bad faith” failure to sit for a deposition in a lawsuit brought by the families of Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting victims, ruled on Wednesday that he would be subject to escalating daily fines for future delays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendan Borrell
title: The Next Big Addiction Treatment
description: Several psychedelic drugs are touted as effective treatments for drug and alcohol abuse. But psilocybin combined with therapy is emerging as the most effective.
content: In recent years there has been a spate of research suggesting psychedelic drugs can help people manage mental health conditions like depression, anxiety, chronic pain or even eating disorders. But a growing body of data points to one as the leading contender to treat the intractable disease of substance abuse. Psilocybin, the active ingredient in psychedelic mushrooms, has shown promise in limited early studies, not only in alcohol and harder drugs, but also nicotine — all of which resist long term treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Luke Vander Ploeg, Mooj Zadie, Paige Cowett, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano, Brad Fisher and Chris Wood
title: How Democrats Evened the Congressional Map
description: This year’s midterm elections could be the fairest in a generation.
content: In the past, Republicans have been able to secure what some see as an unfair political advantage by gerrymandering political districts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: What Putin’s Propaganda Looks Like From Russia and Ukraine
description: Two journalists — one Russian, one Ukrainian — bridge the information iron curtain.
content: The Russia-Ukraine War has been a dangerous time for journalists: Russian troops have kidnapped Ukrainian journalists working in contested territories, and the Kremlin has doubled down on censorship domestically as well, passing a law banning “fake” news about the Russian invasion, with a potential 15-year prison sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miranda Featherstone
title: I’m Tired of Judging Other People’s Covid Choices
description: I don’t want righteous alienation. I want community.
content: The penguins at the New England Aquarium seemed relaxed. Some stood on the rocks, crowing into the humid air above them. Others answered these squawks. They seemed to engage playfully and intimately with one another. The same could not be said of my family and the other guests at the aquarium. Everyone seemed aware of everyone else’s personal space. A mother apologized for her toddler son who stared at me (and my French fries) with rapt interest in the cafe. “He doesn’t get out much,” she said with a laugh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Your World Cup Questions, Answered
description: The tournament doesn’t kick off until November. Here are the basics.
content: The World Cup draw is Friday in Qatar, even though the entire field isn’t yet complete. While we don’t know all the teams, we do know quite a bit about how things will play out. Here’s a primer on the world’s greatest sporting spectacle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed’s favorite inflation gauge climbed 6.4 percent in February.
description: Prices climbed at the fastest pace in four decades over the past year. While economists expect a slowdown, it has yet to materialize.
content: Inflation continued to run at the fastest pace in 40 years in February, fresh data released on Thursday showed, at a moment when war in Ukraine and continued supply chain disruptions tied to the coronavirus promise to keep prices rising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Jackson Vote Poses a Political Dilemma for Murkowski
description: The Alaska Republican is facing a difficult re-election race in which she is under attack by former President Donald J. Trump and the right. Could a vote for President Biden’s nominee save her?
content: WASHINGTON — When President Biden nominated Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to a prestigious appeals court last year, Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, a centrist known for her willingness to break with her party, was one of only three Republicans to vote to confirm her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Is a Gas Tax Holiday on the Agenda in Albany?
description: Giving drivers a break from gas taxes is good politics. But leaders debate whether it’s good policy.
content: Gasoline prices have been on a lot of people’s minds in the last few weeks — even those who don’t drive have watched the figures on service station signs climb in the weeks since Russia invaded Ukraine. Today we’ll look at the prospects for a gas tax holiday in New York and at a brief but intense push in New Jersey to let drivers pump their own fuel at gas stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The World Cup Draw Is Friday. Here’s How It Works.
description: The hard work of qualifying is over. Now the teams headed to Qatar later this year will learn their opponents.
content: The World Cup field is almost complete. On Friday, soccer teams will learn the answer to the critical question they and their fans want to know: Who will they play when the tournament opens in November in Qatar?
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Paris, a Wine Bar Inspired by Tokyo’s Jazz Cafes
description: Plus: a hotel in historic downtown Charleston, S.C., colorful tableware for summer entertaining and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Mihir Zaveri
title: Will Ending a Lucrative Tax Break Ease or Fuel the N.Y.C. Housing Crisis?
description: Few big residential projects have been built without the break, known as 421a, which now costs the city $1.77 billion in lost tax revenue every year.
content: Jackson Park in Queens is a city unto itself: 1,871 luxury apartments in glittering glass towers with a heated rooftop pool, a full-size indoor basketball court and a 1.6-acre private park. Penthouse residences, whose floor-to-ceiling windows offer panoramic Manhattan views, rent for $8,500 a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: For Decades, He Had Strange Episodes of Utter Exhaustion
description: What was causing these spells, and why were they now more frequent?
content: The 51-year-old man sat at his desk preparing for his next online meeting when he suddenly became aware of a familiar stiffness and exhaustion. Had he slept badly? Or was this the beginning of one of his strange episodes? As the symptoms worsened, he had his answer. He knew that when he started to feel this way, the only recourse was to get into bed before he got any weaker. As he made his way slowly down the hall, his legs felt heavy, as if he were wearing ankle weights. Just lifting them was real work. He passed his wife’s home office without a word. She knew just from looking at him that he would probably have to spend the rest of the day in bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Jesse McKinley
title: New York Is About to Blow Its Budget Deadline. Here’s Why.
description: Contentious social issues, such as revising the state’s bail law, have delayed passage of what is expected to be largest budget in the state’s history.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — With a number of knotty issues continuing to stymie negotiations, state leaders seemed intent on blowing past a midnight deadline on Thursday to reach agreement on a new state budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Judge Tosses N.Y. District Lines, Citing Democrats’ ‘Bias’
description: The ruling by a Republican judge would send New York back to the drawing board if upheld and could delay its primaries. Democrats vowed to appeal it.
content: A New York State judge ruled on Thursday that Democrats had unconstitutionally drawn new congressional districts for partisan advantage, and he blocked their use in this year’s election, potentially throwing the midterm contests into turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Safak Timur
title: Prosecutor Asks Turkey to Turn Khashoggi Murder Case Over to Saudis
description: All 26 suspects accused in the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, the dissident Saudi journalist, in Istanbul in 2018 are Saudi nationals.
content: ISTANBUL — A Turkish prosecutor said on Thursday that his country should drop its case against suspects in the killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi, bowing to a demand from Saudi Arabia as Turkey tries to mend relations with the kingdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Graham, Once a Backer of Jackson, Says He Will Oppose Her Confirmation
description: Senator Lindsey Graham voted last year to confirm Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to an influential appeals court. He now calls her an “activist judge” who should not ascend to the Supreme Court.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, said on Thursday that he planned to vote against the confirmation of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court, calling her an “activist judge” who ignored the law to achieve the outcomes she wanted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Storyboard P: Where Is the Place for a Genius of Street Dance?
description: The gap between his category-defying artistry and his career options seems to expose a missing lane in American culture.
content: For a long time, people trying to describe the dancer Storyboard P have reached for grand comparisons and superlatives. He’s the Basquiat of street dancing or a more virtuosic extension of Michael Jackson. He’s the best street dancer in the world or simply the best dancer. To back up these judgments, there is plentiful evidence online: cameos in videos for Jay-Z and high-art films by Arthur Jafa and Kahlil Joseph, appearances in commercials and loads of homemade footage in which he is the star, mind-blowing and one-of-a-kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Many Teens Report Emotional and Physical Abuse by Parents During Lockdown
description: New data on teen mental health during the pandemic suggests that for many, home life was full of stressors like job loss, hunger and even violence.
content: New research from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on adolescents’ mental health during the coronavirus pandemic suggests that for many teenagers who were ordered to stay at home, home was not always a safe place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden will tap oil reserve, hoping to push gasoline prices down.
description: The administration said the president would announce a plan to release reserves of crude daily for six months.
content: Under growing pressure to bring down high energy prices, President Biden announced on Thursday that the United States would release up to 180 million barrels of oil from a strategic reserve to counteract the economic impact of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 5 Fetuses Removed From Home of Anti-Abortion Activist, Group Says
description: The police said they had gone to a home in Washington to investigate a tip about “potential biohazard material” when officers found the fetuses inside. An investigation was continuing.
content: The police said on Thursday that five fetuses had been removed from a home in Washington that, according to an anti-abortion group, belonged to an activist who was charged by the Justice Department this week with blocking access to an abortion clinic in October 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Ben McKenzie Would Like a Word With the Crypto Bros
description: The actor, best known for his starring role in “The O.C.,” has become an outspoken critic of a volatile market driven by speculation. Who’s listening?
content: ROCKDALE, Texas — Ben McKenzie was driving his father’s silver Subaru through Texas farmland, talking in breathless bursts about money: who has it, who needs it, what makes it real or fake. He detailed the perils of cryptocurrency exchanges, the online brokers that sell Bitcoin and Ether to speculators, then delivered a glowing endorsement of “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” a 700-page book by the economist Thomas Piketty about income inequality and the power of wealthy capitalists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Navy Plane Crashes Along Virginia’s Eastern Shore, Killing One Crew Member
description: The five-seat plane crashed on Wednesday evening with three crew members on board, the Navy said. Two were rescued.
content: A small U.S. Navy plane crashed on Wednesday evening along Virginia’s Eastern Shore, killing one crew member and injuring two others, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Faced with foreign pressure, Russians rally around Putin, poll shows.
description: Eighty-three percent of Russians said they approved of Mr. Putin’s actions, up from 69 percent in January, according to an independent pollster in Moscow.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin’s approval ratings have reached levels unseen in years, according to an independent poll released on Thursday, as many Russians rally around the flag in the face of mounting international pressure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
