source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Gagarine’ Review: Head in the Clouds
description: Fanny Liatard and Jérémy Trouilh re-envision the demolition of the housing project Cité Gagarine — an aspirational symbol of French communism — with a heavy dose of magical realism.
content: In August of 2019, Cité Gagarine — a once-aspirational housing project located in the eastern suburbs of Paris, one of the last strongholds of the French Communist Party — was demolished as a crowd of its former residents watched from a distance. In “Gagarine,” by the filmmakers Fanny Liatard and Jérémy Trouilh, this real-life moment is re-envisioned with a heavy dose of magical realism, foregrounding the dreams of a new generation that build upon the structure’s utopian roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Newtown, Conn., and Hartsdale, N.Y.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: State Dept. Will Allow Americans to Mark Their Gender as ‘X’ on Passports
description: The change is aimed at providing transgender, nonbinary or gender-nonconforming Americans a way to accurately identify themselves.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Thursday announced several measures intended to make federal forms of identification, applications for federal programs and travel documents more inclusive for Americans who identify as transgender or nonbinary, or who otherwise do not conform to traditional gender roles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Do We Need to Thank the Wedding Guests Who Didn’t Give Gifts?
description: After hosting her friends for a destination event, a recently married reader wonders who should be thanking whom.
content: My husband and I got married in Palm Springs in October. We live in Los Angeles and encouraged people to come out for the weekend. Apart from the wedding and reception, we hosted a welcome party on Friday and a farewell brunch on Sunday. About a third of our guests did not give us a wedding gift. Most of these people are relatives who flew in from the East Coast. Many of their travel expenses were covered by my grandfather, who put them up for the weekend. Are we still obliged to write thank-you notes to them? I’m inclined not to. I don’t think I need to thank people for going on an expense-paid vacation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn and Adam Powell
title: Kim’s Video Is Back. What Even Is a Video Store in 2022?
description: Alamo Drafthouse bought the seminal New York chain’s collection in an effort to make rentals a draw for moviegoers. Can one disrupted business help another?
content: One day in December, down escalators that led away from the sun and into the bowels of a skyscraper just a few blocks from the New York Stock Exchange, Skip Elsheimer suddenly stopped sifting through a sea of musty, mismatched boxes to marvel at a discovery he held in his dust-coated hands. It was a VHS tape of “Apocalypse Pooh.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Katie Benner and Maggie Haberman
title: Justice Dept. Widens Jan. 6 Inquiry to Range of Pro-Trump Figures
description: Federal prosecutors have been seeking documents and testimony about the fake electors scheme and the planning for the rally just before the storming of the Capitol.
content: Federal prosecutors have substantially widened their Jan. 6 investigation to examine the possible culpability of a broad range of figures involved in former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election, people familiar with the inquiry said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Stephen Merchant Is an Unsmooth Criminal
description: Merchant, a creator of the original “Office” and other series, recruited Christopher Walken for “The Outlaws,” his new Amazon show about community service.
content: Stephen Merchant has made a career out of being uncomfortable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: It’s Scary How Dominant Apple Has Become. But How Scary?
description: What the best picture Oscar for “CODA” tells us about Apple’s enormous market power.
content: How big of a deal is it that a film from Apple, founded as a computer company, just won three Academy Awards, including one for best picture? If you’re among those worried about the inescapable economic, political and cultural dominance of that set of nerdy giants we now call Big Tech, how much greater panic should this induce?
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
description: A veteran conductor’s Bach, a young conductor’s Sibelius, and works by Tom Johnson, Gyorgy Kurtag and Kate Soper are among recent highlights.
content: John Eliot Gardiner has been recording the “St. John Passion” for so long that the countertenor from his first taping of the work, Michael Chance, has been replaced on this new version — Gardiner’s third — by Chance’s son, Alexander. Despite the glimpse of familiarity, Gardiner’s view of this Passion, the one that best suits his operatic flair for drama, has sharpened in the 35 years since his first take. From the stabbing bass line of the opening chorus to the soaring final chorale, there is an unsparing directness to this latest account, which was set down live in Oxford, England, on Good Friday last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: U.S. Seals Its Return to World Cup
description: Five years after a calamitous night cost the U.S. men a World Cup place, a new generation took the field in Costa Rica and claimed a berth in the tournament.
content: SAN JOSÉ, Costa Rica — It was not quite spring break, but the United States men’s soccer team traveled to Costa Rica this week carrying all the stress and psychological burden of second-semester college seniors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Dancing the Night Away With Brazil’s Cia Suave
description: The choreographer Alice Ripoll and 10 dancers from Rio de Janeiro combine youthful abandon with an exploration of social injustice in “Cria” at BAM Fisher.
content: In naming her evening-length work “Cria,” the Brazilian choreographer Alice Ripoll points, in program notes, to its two meanings: a young being (human or animal) and the neighborhood, or favela, from which a person hails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Will Putin Kill the Global Economy?
description: There’s a whiff of 1914 in the air.
content: Economic commentators always reach for historical analogies, and with good reason. For example, those who had studied past banking crises had a much better grasp of what was happening in 2008 than those who hadn’t. But there’s always the question of which analogy to choose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: idyllic
description: This word has appeared in 140 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word idyllic has appeared in 140 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 17 in “How a Stunning Lagoon in Spain Turned Into ‘Green Soup’” by Raphael Minder:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitchell S. Jackson
title: In the Face of Black Pain, Elizabeth Alexander Turns to Art
description: “The Trayvon Generation” traces the influences of racism and violence on American culture today.
content: Dressed in an indelible red coat, Elizabeth Alexander stood aloft the National Mall and faced a sea of expectant faces. Behind her, a platform seated rows upon rows of eminences, including President Barack Obama. In her inaugural poem Alexander likened love to light and closed with lines that bespoke the optimism of the occasion: “On the brink, on the brim, on the cusp,/praise song for walking forward in that light.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: In European Classrooms, Questions About a War So Close to Home
description: As many in Europe have grappled with the shock of facing a war on their doorstep, teachers say they are facing tough questions posed about the conflict by worried children.
content: HORSHAM, England — As they returned from playing tag at recess on a recent sunny morning, the red-cheeked children had lots of questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: What if College Were Free? This State Is Trying to Find Out.
description: As states take the lead in the tuition-free movement after President Biden’s plans failed to gain traction in Congress, New Mexico emerges as a leader.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — As universities across the United States face steep enrollment declines, New Mexico’s government is embarking on a pioneering experiment to fight that trend: tuition-free higher education for all state residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Museum Show Highlights Media-Makers on the Autism Spectrum
description: The first Marvels of Media at the Museum of the Moving Image includes an awards ceremony, a festival and an exhibition.
content: When his autistic son, Nate, was growing up, Josh Sapan used to take him to the Museum of the Moving Image in Queens where the video game exhibitions helped Nate connect to the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: NATO sees evidence that Russian troops are regrouping, not withdrawing from around Kyiv.
description: “Russia has repeatedly lied about its intentions,” NATO’s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg said of Moscow’s pledge to pull back from Kyiv. “So we can only judge Russia on its actions, not on its words.”
content: BRUSSELS — Despite Russian statements that it would radically reduce its military activity around Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, to concentrate on the war in eastern Ukraine, Western governments see little evidence of that, Jens Stoltenberg, the NATO secretary-general, told a news conference on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Clifford Krauss
title: Soaring Cost of Diesel Ripples Through the Global Economy
description: Russia’s war in Ukraine has caused a steep rise in a fuel essential to truckers, farmers and industry. Europe is hardest hit.
content: Farmers are spending more to keep tractors and combines running. Shipping and trucking companies are passing higher costs to retailers, which are beginning to pass them on to shoppers. And local governments are paying hundreds of thousands of dollars extra to fill up school buses. Construction costs could soon rise, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Patricia Mazzei and Nick Corasaniti
title: Judge Rules Parts of Florida Voting Law Are Unconstitutional
description: The ruling against a major Republican election law, issued by a federal judge in Tallahassee, is likely to be overturned either by a higher appeals court or the U.S. Supreme Court.
content: A federal judge in Florida ruled on Thursday that sections of the state’s year-old election law were unconstitutional and racially motivated, and barred the state from making similar changes to its laws in the next decade without the approval of the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Apollo 10½: A Space Age Childhood’ Review: OK, Boomer
description: Richard Linklater’s new animated film tells the story of the moon landing with some tongue-in-cheek revisionism.
content: There are some people out there who insist that the moon landing never happened. As far as I know, the director Richard Linklater is not among them, but his new movie whimsically proposes its own revisionist account of what NASA was up to in the summer of 1969. Before Neil Armstrong took his giant leap, it seems, a Texas fourth grader named Stan stepped out of the landing module and onto the lunar surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joy Dong and Austin Ramzy
title: In Hong Kong, China’s Covid Aid Gets the Cold Shoulder
description: Disputes about medics, squat toilets and diaper-changing duties underscore longstanding tensions between residents of Hong Kong and the mainland.
content: HONG KONG — Soon after Omicron overwhelmed Hong Kong’s health care system in a deadly outbreak, Beijing rushed to help. Contractors from mainland China built vast isolation facilities. The central government sent more than 1,000 medical workers to staff treatment and testing centers, as well as butchers to help stabilize the local meat supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How a Music Executive Spends His Sundays
description: In the 1990s, Jamie Krents was on tour with an indie rock group. Now he’s a family man in Brooklyn.
content: Verve Label Group, which includes American jazz, classical and other eclectic labels, racked up 21 Grammy Award nominations this year (Jon Batiste, a contender in the record of the year and album of the year categories, was responsible for 11 of them).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Australian Journalist Who Worked for Chinese Media Stands Trial in Beijing
description: Cheng Lei, a former CGTN host, was detained in 2020. The Chinese authorities have accused her of divulging state secrets but offered no specifics.
content: Almost 20 months after she was detained in Beijing, an Australian journalist who worked for China’s global television network stood trial behind closed doors on Thursday, accused of sending state secrets abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Texas Student Who Protested Pledge of Allegiance Gets $90,000 in Settlement
description: Mari Oliver claimed in a federal lawsuit that she was harassed for opting out of reciting the pledge as a high school student.
content: In Texas, state law requires students to pledge allegiance daily to the flags of the United States and of the Lone Star State. As a high school student in Spring, Texas, Mari Oliver sat silently during this daily recitation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Takeover’
description: In 1970, the Young Lords, a Puerto Rican activist group, occupied a hospital in the Bronx demanding safer and more accessible health care for the community. What can we learn from this overlooked history?
content: Note to teachers: This week’s film is longer than a typical Film Club feature. If you have limited class time, there are several natural stopping points during the documentary, such as at 12:56 or 18:53.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Morbius’ Review: The Other Bat, Man
description: Jared Leto bares his teeth as a neo-vampire who walks by day and tries to keep his monstrous thirst at bay in the latest Marvel adaptation.
content: My, what sharp teeth he has — and what lovely skin, too. One of the revelations of “Morbius” — the latest movie to take a marginal Marvel character out of mothballs for his blockbuster close-up — is that regular blood smoothies do wonders for the skin. To judge by the chiseled planes of Morbius’s arms and torso, pounding shots of the slurpy stuff also builds muscles much faster than mainlining anabolic steroids can.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Myanmar Junta’s Political Prisoners Since Coup Now Number 10,000
description: Most are held in deplorable conditions and face certain conviction at trial. Rights groups say the Southeast Asian nation now has the worst human rights conditions in the region.
content: The military junta that seized power in Myanmar 14 months ago is now detaining 10,000 political prisoners, a rights organization that monitors detentions said on Thursday. Many of the prisoners have been tortured and are being held in deplorable conditions, according to the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Nancy Milford, Biographer of Zelda Fitzgerald, Dies at 84
description: Her penetrating book about F. Scott Fitzgerald’s troubled wife was a best seller. So was her biography of another Jazz Age luminary, the poet Edna St. Vincent Millay.
content: Nancy Milford, the biographer of women who helped light up the Jazz Age — Zelda Fitzgerald, the “original flapper” and wife and literary muse of F. Scott Fitzgerald, and the poet Edna St. Vincent Millay — died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Adam Zagoria
title: In Coaching, It’s Sometimes About Who You Know and Where You’ve Been
description: Coaches of several N.C.A.A. tournament teams either attended their universities, like North Carolina’s Hubert Davis, or started their careers there, like Kansas’ Bill Self.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Just before his senior season at Oklahoma State, Bill Self injured a knee while working as a basketball camp counselor at the University of Kansas. Each time he saw Larry Brown, who was then the Jayhawks’ coach, the limp got worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Can Republicans Win by Just Saying No?
description: History suggests that opposing the party in power is often good enough.
content: In the 1946 midterms, Republicans united around a simple but powerful mantra: “Had enough?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Jerrod Carmichael has a potent new special and Christopher Walken is doing community service.
content: ‘Jerrod Carmichael: Rothaniel’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael H. Keller
title: Adults or Sexually Abused Minors? Getting It Right Vexes Facebook
description: The company reports millions of photos and videos of suspected child sexual abuse each year. But when ages are unclear, young people are treated as adults and the images are not reported to the authorities.
content: Facebook is a leader among tech companies in detecting child sexual abuse content, which has exploded on social media and across the internet in recent years. But concerns about mistakenly accusing people of posting illegal imagery have resulted in a policy that could allow photos and videos of abuse to go unreported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Babi Yar: Context’ Review: Unearthing Footage of a Nazi Massacre
description: Sergei Loznitsa’s new documentary, about the mass murder of Ukrainian Jews in 1941, arrives in theaters with a grim context of its own.
content: Over two days in September, 1941, German soldiers, assisted by Ukrainian collaborators, murdered 33,771 Jews at the Babi Yar ravine outside Kyiv. The massacre was one of the earliest and deadliest episodes in what is sometimes called the “holocaust by bullets,” a phase of the Nazi genocide that took place outside the mechanized slaughter of the death camps. These mobile killing squads, known as Einsatzgruppen, are estimated to have taken at least 1.5 million lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger and Quoctrung Bui
title: Can Home Prices and Interest Rates Soar at the Same Time?
description: Rising mortgage rates are supposed to cool house prices. But this time could be different.
content: It’s getting more expensive by the moment to buy a home in America. Mortgage interest rates, historically low during most of the pandemic, are rising faster than they have in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: After a Boycott, Chinese Television Is Again Airing N.B.A. Games
description: China Central Television stopped showing the games in 2019 after a Houston Rockets executive expressed support for pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong.
content: China Central Television, China’s state-run TV network, has begun to broadcast N.B.A. games again, signaling that the rift between the league and the authoritarian government that has persisted since 2019 appears to be coming to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 24 New Words Invented by Teenagers
description: We invited students to suggest words to fill gaps in the English language. Here are our favorites.
content: Most of the time, editors at The Learning Network select vocabulary words and invite students to practice using them in real-life contexts. But in February, we flipped the script: We asked young people to turn a critical eye on our lexicon and consider what might be missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Hyperbole and Horror of Ginni Thomas
description: The messages are a terrifying glimpse into the right’s madness.
content: A week has gone by and I’m still aghast. Still astonished. Still absorbing what Ginni Thomas said in those text messages to Mark Meadows, President Donald Trump’s chief of staff, as she urged him to overturn the 2020 election, and what she apparently believes in her poisoned mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Inside the Energy War
description: The U.S. and Europe are taking steps to secure oil and gas supplies.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Alex Traub
title: Paul Herman, Mainstay of Gangster Movies, Is Dead at 76
description: Over a four-decade career, he was perhaps best known for his role on “The Sopranos.” But he also had dozens of film credits, including “Goodfellas” and “The Irishman.”
content: Paul Herman, who put in appearances as wiseguys and schlemiels in movies like Martin Scorsese’s “Goodfellas” and “Casino” and three seasons of “The Sopranos,” died on Tuesday, his 76th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Two Covid Problems
description: The U.S. may soon run out of Covid money. That’s not the only problem.
content: The short-term and long-term flaws with the country’s current Covid-19 policy are quite different.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The 1,328-Page Novel That Captivated the Primatologist Frans de Waal
description: “Haruki Murakami’s trilogy ’1Q84’ kept me spellbound for all of its 1,328 pages, which is unusual for me. Such an unrealistic story, yet so realistically told.”
content: “Haruki Murakami’s trilogy ’1Q84’ kept me spellbound for all of its 1,328 pages, which is unusual for me,” says the biologist Frans de Waal, whose latest book is “Different: Gender Through the Eyes of a Primatologist.” “Such an unrealistic story, yet so realistically told.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Macron Goes on Defensive Over Use of McKinsey and Other Consultants
description: President Emmanuel Macron’s opponents have criticized the French government for paying at least a billion dollars last year to private consulting firms.
content: PARIS — In a sedate presidential race overshadowed by pandemic and war, it’s the one issue that has so far managed to ruffle an otherwise supremely confident President Emmanuel Macron: McKinsey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Why the Sudden Urge to Reconsider Famous Women?
description: Pop culture has never been more interested in reclaiming women from the recent past, like Pamela Anderson and Janet Jackson. But not every reclamation succeeds.
content: In a scene from the FX series “Impeachment: American Crime Story,” Monica Lewinsky (Beanie Feldstein) sits in her darkened apartment in the Watergate complex. Puffy eyed and pale, she watches herself pilloried on late-night television. David Letterman makes her the subject of a Top 10 list. Jay Leno begins his monologue with a barrage of Monica jokes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: The head of the C.I.A. tests positive and has mild symptoms.
description: William J. Burns got the positive result a day after meeting with President Biden.
content: William J. Burns, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, tested positive for the coronavirus on Thursday, a day after meeting with President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Adriana Hoffmann, Botanist Who Fought for Chile’s Forests, Dies at 82
description: The U.N. recognized her as one of the top 25 environmental leaders of the 1990s, championing her nation’s natural resources in the face of corporate power.
content: Adriana Hoffmann, a botanist who roamed Chile deciphering its flora and who as a scientist, activist, author and policymaker tirelessly sought to protect her country’s vast forests from big-business exploitation, died on March 20 at her home in Santiago, the capital. She was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: Ireland’s Last ‘Magdalene Laundry’ Will Become a Memorial
description: A compound in Dublin where unmarried mothers and other unwanted women were incarcerated to work in abject conditions had been earmarked as a site for a budget hotel.
content: DUBLIN — Ireland’s last surviving “Magdalene laundry,” where thousands of unmarried mothers and other unwanted women were forced to work without pay in abject conditions, often until they died, is to be preserved as a state-funded memorial to all victims of incarceration and abuse in church and state-run institutions, the Irish government has announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Yes, Lynching Is Still a Thing
description: A new law that makes lynching a federal hate crime addresses an atrocity that continues to this day.
content: On a warm August night in 1955 on the outskirts of Money, Miss., about a hundred miles due north of Jackson, two men arrived with a flashlight and a gun at the house where Emmett Till was staying with his aunt and uncle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: House Passes Bill to Limit Cost of Insulin to $35 a Month
description: The bill stands to benefit millions of Americans with diabetes, but to become law, it will need to attract at least 10 Republican votes in the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — A bill to limit the cost of insulin to $35 a month for most Americans who depend on it passed the House on Thursday, raising Democrats’ hopes that the party could take at least one step toward fulfilling its promise of lowering drug costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Vegetarian Pastas I’m Craving
description: After some time away from home, nothing satisfies like vegetable Bolognese.
content: I’ve been on the road, and I can’t wait to have a simple dinner at home — something like spaghetti with a vegetable-packed tomato sauce and a salad, probably. It’s not just the dinner! It’s the quiet afternoon in my kitchen that comes before it, the time to take care of stuff like emptying out the compost, or sharpening a knife, or cleaning a cast-iron while my dogs hang out and snore in their beds. After I’ve been away, a day like this can feel so luxurious.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Covid has been with us long enough that it’s steadily showing up in books now — and good ones, not just the rushed-out clip jobs that try to capitalize on readers’ fickle attention spans. This week we recommend an E.R. doctor’s memoir of life in the pandemic (Thomas Fisher’s “The Emergency”), as well as two novels that both incorporate Covid as a plot point, Anne Tyler’s “French Braid” and Sarah Moss’s “The Fell.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Hugs to Boring
description: Don’t underestimate the tech that makes your eyes glaze over. It holds us all up.
content: This week, a company I never think about scooped up another one I had forgotten existed. It was a reminder that we shouldn’t underestimate the boring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Powerful Storm Kills at Least 2 in Florida Panhandle
description: At least two others were injured, the authorities said. The damage came a day after a tornado destroyed buildings and left several injured in Arkansas.
content: At least two people were killed and two others were injured when a severe storm destroyed homes and toppled trees in the Florida Panhandle early on Thursday morning, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: A Nation of Spy-Catchers: Fear of Saboteurs Has Ukrainians on Edge
description: There are checkpoints, hotlines and apps for reporting suspicious activities. Ukrainians worry about saboteurs mixing among them, sowing mistrust and spreading misinformation.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Two weeks after Valeriy, an actor and amateur photographer, settled in western Ukraine after fleeing his home in Kyiv, he was stopped and questioned by the local police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The S.E.C. Takes Aim at SPACs
description: A new proposal casts an even bigger shadow over the once-booming market for blank-check firms.
content: The S.E.C. voted yesterday to propose new rules for special purpose acquisition companies, casting an even bigger shadow over the once-booming market. If adopted, these public shell companies — formed to acquire a business and take it public without the fuss of the traditional I.P.O. process — would have to provide more investor disclosures, especially about their ownership and performance forecasts. In some cases, SPACs may have to register as investment companies, subjecting them to stricter rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Russian attacks on Ukraine.
content: A day after Russia made claims of de-escalation, it increased bomb and artillery attacks in Ukraine and sent conflicting signals about the prospects for peace, suggesting new tensions in the Kremlin hierarchy about the course of the war. Follow the latest updates from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Moonshot’ Review: Found in Space
description: Cole Sprouse and Lana Condor have a meet-cute en route to Mars in the young adult rom-com “Moonshot,” streaming on HBO Max.
content: Christopher Winterbauer’s future-set “Moonshot” is built around a familiar, hard-to-resist premise, most often found in sitcoms but with roots in 1930s screwball comedies: a man and a woman who don’t get along must pretend to be romantically involved for the purpose of an elaborate ruse, the advancement of which gradually brings them closer together until they fall in love for real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘The Rose Maker’ Review: Purloined Blossoms for a Blue Lady
description: A boutique cultivator competing with industrial farms initiates a war of the roses in this gentle French comedy by Pierre Pinaud.
content: The first flowers to grace the opening credits of this gentle French comedy are white roses in full bloom. Their petals are unblemished, and their milky hue seems luminous, a reminder that what appears to be white is a reflection of all colors. Horticulturists know it’s not easy to grow a perfect rose, and that principle will become the cornerstone of the plot in “The Rose Maker.” The film indicates its cinematic commitment with the perfection of these first roses — their almost shocking vibrancy complimented by a jovial Dean Martin tune. It’s easy for characters to say they grow such a flower, and another achievement entirely for filmmakers to find one to display onscreen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Condemns Trump’s Digging for Dirt During a War
description: “It’s generally frowned upon for U.S. presidents, current or former, to solicit our murderous mortal enemies for dirt on their political rivals,” Colbert said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: How Rose Matafeo Shaped the Romance in ‘Starstruck’
description: The comedian drew on her love of classic Hollywood, anime and funny women to create her HBO Max show.
content: LONDON — For Rose Matafeo, there’s just something about a classic love story. Particularly movies from Hollywood’s golden age, featuring heartthrobs with trans-Atlantic accents, witty female leads and zero cynicism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Russia’s War Lacks a Battlefield Commander, U.S. Officials Say
description: Poor logistics and flagging morale have plagued a disjointed military campaign in Ukraine, according to American officials and independent analysts.
content: WASHINGTON — Russia is running its military campaign against Ukraine out of Moscow, with no central war commander on the ground to call the shots, according to American officials who have studied the five-week-old war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC and Russia stick to a modest oil increase.
description: The oil producers insist that the oil market is “well balanced” despite the Ukraine war and sanctions against Russia.
content: With analysts warning of a coming oil supply crunch, OPEC and its allies, including Russia, decided on Thursday to stick with their previously agreed plan of modest monthly increases. The group, known as OPEC Plus, said it would increase oil output in May by 432,000 barrels a day, a slight uptick from the usual increase of 400,000 barrels a day for technical reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Maggie Haberman
title: She Took the White House Photos. Trump Moved to Take the Profit.
description: The former chief White House photographer made plans to publish a book of Trump photos. The former president had other plans.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Donald J. Trump’s tenure came to an end, the chief White House photographer, who had traveled the world with him and spent countless hours inside the White House snapping pictures, notified Mr. Trump’s aides that she intended to publish a book collecting some of her most memorable images.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden Invokes Cold War Statute to Boost Critical Mineral Supply
description: The action aims to enhance American production of crucial materials for electric vehicles, defense systems and other technologies.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden took steps on Thursday to try to increase domestic production of critical minerals and metals needed for advanced technologies like electric vehicles, in an attempt to reduce America’s reliance on foreign suppliers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Rebecca Serle Met Her Mom’s Old Boyfriend, Then Wrote a Best Seller
description: ‘One Italian Summer’ was inspired by a meaningful encounter during an intergenerational pilgrimage to Positano and Rome.
content: MAMMA MIA What would you give to be able to spend time with your mother as a young woman, before life’s obligations and turning points landed with a thud on her shoulders? In “One Italian Summer,” now in its fourth week on the hardcover fiction list, Rebecca Serle immerses her protagonist in this fantasy. The circumstances are bittersweet for Katy Silver, who proceeds with a long-planned vacation to the Amalfi Coast after Carol, her mother and intended traveling companion, dies of cancer. There, in the lobby of her hotel in Positano, she runs into a 30-year-old incarnation of Carol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
title: Imran Khan Defiantly Refuses to Resign as Pakistan’s Leader
description: Prime Minister Khan, who faces the prospect of being removed from office by Parliament, accused the United States of mounting a conspiracy to topple his government.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Facing the near certain prospect of being removed from office in a no-confidence vote in a matter of days, Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan refused to resign in a defiant speech on Thursday, doubling down on his allegations of a foreign conspiracy against him and deepening a political crisis that has embroiled the country for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Bad Is California’s Drought Ahead of Dry Season?
description: Moving into April means the end of the state’s rainy season — and hope of improving drought conditions.
content: Today marks the final day of California’s rainy season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas and Ken Belson
title: Retiring as Coach, Bruce Arians Joins the Buccaneers’ Front Office
description: Arians left a previous retirement to coach Tampa Bay in 2019 and won a title after the 2020 season. Todd Bowles, the defensive coordinator and a former Jets head coach, will succeed him.
content: Bruce Arians, who coached the Tampa Bay Buccaneers for the past three seasons and led the team to a Super Bowl title, will become a consultant in the team’s front office, the team announced Wednesday night. Todd Bowles, Tampa Bay’s defensive coordinator, will replace Arians as head coach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korean ICBM Launch May Have Been Fake. It’s Still Important.
description: South Korea says Kim Jong-un disguised an older missile as a new one to exaggerate his country’s weapons achievements when he badly needs political leverage.
content: SEOUL — When North Korea conducted its most powerful intercontinental ballistic missile test to date​ last week​, it said it launched the Hwasong-17, its newest and biggest ICBM. In a propaganda blitz, the country’s state media released a Hollywood-style video of its leader, Kim Jong-un, personally guiding the test launch in a sleek leather jacket and sunglasses at Pyongyang International Airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | April 6, 2022
description: Where should we be taking steps to protect biodiversity to slow down plant and animal extinction?
content: This map shows the concentration of imperiled biodiversity of plants and animals in the lower 48 states. More than 2,200 species and their habitat needs were studied by NatureServe, the source of this map. Areas with high concentration have more species at high risk of global extinction. Superimposed on this map are the areas that are permanently protected for biodiversity by federal, state and local entities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Final Fours in the Same City? Not Anytime Soon.
description: An idea that has bounced around college sports for years will not be used for at least another decade.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Separated by about 1,000 miles and decades of fragmentation, the N.C.A.A. will stage an eight-team, four-day, two-city carnival of college basketball starting on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: A highlight of the art world’s gradual return to business as usual is the reintroduction of the Brooklyn Museum’s First Saturdays. The institution offered First Saturday Lite events last summer, but on Saturday the treasured monthly tradition returns in full for the first time since March 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Bull’ Review: Vengeance Is His
description: The British crime thriller plays out a meat-and-potatoes (or bangers-and-mash) revenge story with suitable menace and more than a dash of Grand Guignol.
content: The British crime thriller “Bull” is named after a small-time gangster seeking vengeance, but it could be short for “bullet.” Compact, lethal and nearly unstoppable, Bull (Neil Maskell) hits his targets, one after another, even though he can look like a scruffy dad, which he also is. He’s on the war path against Norm (David Hayman, with a face of placid malice), his former boss, whose daughter, Gemma, he married. (They have a son.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Zerofsky
title: France’s Far Right Turn
description: A rising nationalist faction has grown its coalition by appealing to Catholic identity and anti-immigrant sentiment — and reshaped the country’s race for president.
content: With only one month to go until France’s presidential election in April, the office of Marine Le Pen, the leader of the French far-right party the National Rally, sent the usual Sunday email outlining her schedule for the coming week as “candidate for the presidency of the Republic.” Unfortunately for Le Pen, many of its recipients were at that moment en route to a rally for her rival, where several formerly trusted members of her inner circle would fill the front row. Ever since Éric Zemmour, a far-right pundit and former newspaper columnist, declared his own candidacy for president last November, members of Le Pen’s party had been departing in a steady trickle for his. And yet there was something particularly plaintive in Le Pen’s notification. A final defection was expected that day — that of her niece, Marion Maréchal, quite likely spelling the end of Le Pen and of her party’s hold over the far right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Want to See the Weirdest of Wikipedia? Look No Further.
description: On @depthsofwikipedia, Annie Rauwerda is compiling some of the crowdsourced site’s most bizarre pages.
content: Did you know that there’s a Swiss political party dedicated to opposing the use of PowerPoint? That some people believe Avril Lavigne died in 2003 and was replaced by a look-alike? Or that there’s a stone in a museum in Taiwan that uncannily resembles a slab of meat?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Better Nate Than Ever’ Review: Castaway Seeks Broadway
description: Hearty performances elevate this effusive Disney+ family comedy, even as the movie itself is awkward in its handling of its core subject.
content: Nate Foster (Rueby Wood), the stage-struck seventh grader at the center of “Better Nate Than Ever,” is “different,” according to his father (Norbert Leo Butz). How so? Classroom discussion of the heavily implied answer to that question has recently come under fire in Florida — and isn’t directly stated in this shiny, otherwise effusive Disney+ family comedy. But it is signified with various degrees of directness: A rainbow-striped rabbit’s foot dangles from Nate’s backpack, and at one point it is revealed that Nate, a member of Generation Z, somehow has memorized a monologue from a 1986 episode of “Designing Women,” originally delivered by Dixie Carter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Moscow calls U.S. intelligence on Putin’s military advice a ‘complete misunderstanding.’
description: The Kremlin spokesman also played down the prospect of an April meeting between Presidents Vladimir V. Putin and Volodymyr Zelensky.
content: The Kremlin on Thursday dismissed American intelligence showing that President Vladimir V. Putin has been misinformed about his military’s struggles in Ukraine, and warned that such a “complete misunderstanding” of the situation in Moscow could have “bad consequences.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Contractor’ Review: The Pine Identity
description: Chris Pine and Ben Foster team up to play mercenaries in a solid thriller about losing your faith and finding yourself in a violent reckoning.
content: Chris Pine often seems too pretty, too nice, decent and, well, intelligent for his movies. He’s comfortable sharing the screen with both men and women, and can persuasively shift registers, all while letting you see him thinking, not just emoting. His range elevates action movies like “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit,” a 2014 take on the Tom Clancy property. Even so, I forgot that I’d reviewed “Jack Ryan” until I looked it up recently. Like too many of Pine’s movies, it just didn’t stick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marissa Hermanson
title: Even With High Gas Prices, the Open Road Still Beckons
description: Itineraries may change, and less money may be spent on food and lodgings, but road trips historically haven’t been stopped by the price at the pump.
content: With her 11-year-old cat, Prince, resting on the center console of her Honda CR-V, Michele Peters recently drove 13 hours south from her home in Chesapeake, Va., to Osprey, Fla., for some much-needed rest and relaxation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: The Library Ends Late Fees, and the Treasures Roll In
description: The decision by the New York Public Library set off a wave of returns, accompanied by bashful notes of apology and gratitude.
content: Some items, checked out decades ago, arrived with apologetic notes. “Enclosed are books I have borrowed and kept in my house for 28-50 years! I am 75 years old now and these books have helped me through motherhood and my teaching career,” one patron wrote in an unsigned letter that accompanied a box of books dropped off at the New York Public Library’s main branch last fall. “I’m sorry for living with these books so long. They became family.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Ways to Read, Write, Teach and Learn Poetry With The New York Times
description: Here are 30 ideas for helping your students appreciate poetry — and experiment with it themselves.
content: “Thank goodness for poetry,” wrote Sindha Agha, the video artist who made the piece at the top of this post. “A poem is a timeless place, an immaterial plot of land where we can gather across generations to breathe and feel, deeply and safely.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad and Asmaa al-Omar
title: Syrian Mercenaries Deploy to Russia en Route to Ukrainian Battlefields
description: A first contingent has arrived in Russia for military training including members of a Syrian unit that worked with Russian officers in Syria, backing President Bashar al-Assad.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hundreds of Syrian fighters are en route to join Russian forces in Ukraine, effectively returning the favor to Moscow for helping President Bashar al-Assad crush rebels in an 11-year civil war, according to two people monitoring the flow of mercenaries.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, March 31, 2022.
content: An article on Wednesday about people fleeing the Ukrainian city of Chernihiv misstated the city’s location. It is on the left bank of the Desna River, not the Dnieper River.

title: Regulators raid companies involved in natural gas in Europe.
description: Media reports linked the raids to subsidiaries of Gazprom, the Russian gas giant.
content: BERLIN — European Union and German regulators carried out unannounced inspections at several companies involved in the supply, transmission and storage of natural gas, on suspicion of violating E.U. competition regulations, the authorities said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Men’s Final Four Is All About the Hue of the Blue
description: Each team in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball Final Four — North Carolina, Duke, Kansas and Villanova — uses a shade of blue as a primary color. And each will tell you its blue is the most true.

author: By Melissa Eddy and Patricia Cohen
title: European leaders again reject Russia’s demand that gas deliveries be paid in rubles.
description: Existing contracts that allow for payments in Western currencies must be upheld, European leaders insist, while economists contemplate Vladimir Putin’s motives.
content: European leaders on Thursday pushed back against President Vladimir V. Putin’s latest threat that all natural gas imported from Russia must be paid for in rubles starting Friday — or risk having the supplies shut off. Mr. Putin said in a TV address that companies purchasing gas from Russia would need to open ruble accounts in Russian banks, effective Friday, and pay for the gas through those accounts.

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Either End of a School Bus
description: Oliver Roeder either gets rid of something or draws attention to it, depending on your viewpoint.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Were you a doodler in school? I was. To the teacher, I was a daydreamer. But it felt as if I heard the teacher better as long as little cubes, pyramids and other assorted geometric shapes were flowing from my pen. Counterintuitively, doodling around the edges of my work helped me focus. It wasn’t until I was an adult that I learned that this type of activity was actually helpful to those with attention deficit disorders. Live and learn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Facing Demand for Labor, U.S. to Provide 35,000 More Seasonal Worker Visas
description: Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the secretary of homeland security, said the decision was meant to help American businesses in need of workers as the summer approaches.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration, responding to an increasing demand for temporary workers, announced on Thursday that it would make an additional 35,000 seasonal worker visas available for American businesses to hire foreign workers ahead of the coming summer months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Plan Would Release a Million Barrels of Oil a Day From Reserve
description: A release of up to 180 million barrels in all, over 180 days, is aimed at helping ease prices at the pump.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden is considering a plan to release one million barrels of oil a day from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve for as long as 180 days, a move that would add a large amount of oil to the global market, according to a person familiar with the White House deliberations on the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: After Record-Setting Run With St. Peter’s, Shaheen Holloway Leaves for Seton Hall
description: Just days after his team became the first No. 15 seed to play in the round of 8, Holloway is returning to the university where he once starred in the backcourt.
content: Shaheen Holloway, who stepped into the national spotlight as the coach of the plucky St. Peter’s Peacocks during their deep run through this year’s N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, left the university on Wednesday to become the head coach at Seton Hall.

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: A Playwright Makes the Scene in New York’s Living Rooms
description: Matthew Gasda spent years writing plays on his electric typewriter, and almost no one seemed to care. With “Dimes Square,” his depiction of a downtown crowd, he has an underground hit.
content: In the fall of 2020, a young playwright named Matthew Gasda decided to entertain some friends by staging a one-act drama on a grassy hilltop of Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn. The masked audience quickly realized that what they were watching was conspicuously relatable: Performed on a picnic blanket by seven actors, “Circles” presented a group of pandemic-weary friends who gather over wine one night in a city park to catch up on their lives.

title: Seven Decades Later, the 1950 Census Bares Its Secrets
description: Federal law kept the answers on millions of census forms secret for 72 years. The forms went online on Friday, a bonanza for historians, genealogists and the merely curious.
content: WASHINGTON — At 12:01 a.m. on Friday, precisely 72 years after enumerators began knocking on the doors of some 46 million American houses and apartments, the federal government made public what they learned: the ages, incomes, addresses, ancestry and a trove of other facts about the 150.7 million people who were counted in the 1950 census.

title: A Shuttered Bar’s Low-Alcohol Drinks Live On in a New Book

content: Most bar owners write cocktail books to draw attention to their business. But in September 2020, the bartender Natasha David sat down to finish a book filled with drink recipes from a bar that no longer existed.

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Putin ‘Just Threw Over the Chess Board,’ and Russians Feel Shame and Dismay
description: Once again, Russia has become a pariah spreading lies and death.
content: It is hard to feel sorry for Russia today, when its army is savaging Ukraine. But for those of us who were in Moscow on that August morning in 1991 when a warm sun rose over people massed outside the “White House,” the embattled seat of the Russian government, and we realized that the tanks were not coming, that the coup had failed, that the Soviet yoke had been lifted, it’s also hard to escape a deep sense of grief that Russia has come full circle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: The African Artist-Writer Who Mapped New Worlds
description: In 1948, Frédéric Bruly Bouabré had a vision that led him to invent a new writing system. The Museum of Modern Art explores his more than 1,000 drawings.
content: African art has had a place at the Museum of Modern Art from its earliest days — though not the African art you might think. In 1935, back when the museum nestled into a townhouse on West 53rd Street, the curator James Johnson Sweeney organized “African Negro Art,” whose 600 specimens included Dogon painted masks, Baoulé ivories and bangles and Congolese seats and spoons. It was one of the most popular exhibitions of MoMA’s first decade, and toured the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Kenya’s Supreme Court Rejects President’s Plan to Amend Constitution
description: Civil society groups had criticized the proposal as an attempt to expand presidential power and strengthen the elite’s grip on national politics.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenya’s top court on Thursday quashed an initiative by the president to amend the Constitution, dealing a major blow to a plan that could have cemented his ability to shape the country’s political future ahead of an election that will decide his successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Slow Horses’ Review: Tinker Tailor Soldier Failure
description: Gary Oldman stars as an MI5 has-been in a darkly comic thriller about the spies no one wants to talk about.
content: When he wrote “Slow Horses,” the first of his Slough House series of alt-spy thrillers, the British novelist Mick Herron helpfully included some casting advice. He described his most vivid character, Jackson Lamb, perhaps a bit redundantly, as “Timothy Spall gone to seed.”

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Income Taxes for All? Rick Scott Has a Plan, and That’s a Problem.
description: The “Plan to Rescue America” is dividing the party and cheering Democrats, and its author, Senate Republicans’ top campaign official, won’t stop talking about it.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Rick Scott of Florida, the somewhat embattled head of the Senate Republicans’ campaign arm, said one utterly indisputable thing on Thursday when he stood before a packed auditorium of supporters at the conservative Heritage Foundation: His plan for a G.O.P. majority would make everyone angry at him, Republicans included.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden Releases Oil Reserves
description: The war in Ukraine is snarling global energy supply.
content: On Thursday, the White House announced a plan to release up to 180 million barrels of oil from U.S. strategic reserves, the largest release since it was created, hoping to push gas prices down.  Oil prices, which had been surging since the fighting in Ukraine began, fell modestly on expectations of the announcement. But diesel prices are still soaring.
